subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Milligan poems
msgSnippet: I noticed that in my recent post in which I wrote about the way an alphabet was intended to work:  one sound = one phoneme.  Of course, I meant to write one
messageBody:
I noticed that in my recent post in which I wrote about the way an
alphabet was intended to work: "one sound = one phoneme." Of course, I
meant to write "one symbol = one phoneme"

Your experience with /Faerie Queene /matches my expectation that
occasional aberrant spellings are not the end of the world. And, as you
say, the only way to test how much of a problem it is by reading the
spelling of people from different speech communities. When I
corresponded with a gentleman from New Zealand in 1975, I don't remember
having any particular difficulty in reading his QS.

I think a periodical in QS would be great. Who wants to get this
organized? Don't everyone volunteer at once. :-) Where could we get
copy that isn't copyrighted that we could just transliterate into QS?

Paige

Benjamin Bruce wrote:
>
> While reading Paige's message about standardized spelling, I
> thought about how English-speaking folks lived without it back during
> the Renaissance period. I myself am reading Edmund Spenser's Faerie
> Queene (1590) right now, and even though there are no J's, and V's and
> U's change depending on whether the letter appears at the beginning of
> a word, I am not having any trouble reading it, even with the
> irregularity of spelling.
>
> What I think more than anything will prove what we're talking about
> (not proving that someone's right or wrong, but testing the situation
> itself) is actual usage. Were someone to start a periodical in
> Quickscript as discussed earlier, with contributors from varying
> locations, it seems to me that the only concern for the materials
> would be that they actually do match the spoken language, and are not
> just errors made from thinking in traditional orthography. We can
> talk all day long about how things could be, but the only thing that
> matters is how things are or will be in actuality.
>
> -Benjamin Bruce
> BenjaminBruce.com
>
> 2007/9/10, pgabhart <pgabhart@...
> <mailto:pgabhart@...>>:
>
> First, I disagree with the statement "QS is meant to be heard." Not
> meaning to be categorical, but QS is an attempt to realign English
> with
> an alphabet that works the way an alphabet is supposed to: one
> sound =
> one phoneme. The QS manual starts off with the reasons why trying to
> redesign the Roman alphabet just doesn't cut it. A new alphabet
> was needed.
>
> The problem I see with standardized spelling is that the
> "English-speaking Peoples" have no language academy to even
> attempt to
> enforce spelling changes as the language continues to evolve. That is
> sort of how we got in this mess (TO) to begin with.
>
> I may be abysmally ignorant of the extent of English dialects, but I
> suspect that for a very large majority of English speakers, i.e. the
> ones clustered in the middle of the bell curve of English
> pronunciation,
> we could get along just fine without a standardized spelling
> because the
> majority of the words we use on a daily basis are not going to be
> spelt
> so peculiarly by someone from a different, but still one of the major
> speech communities that it would not be recognizable. To be sure,
> there
> are the outliers on that bell curve who would need to conform their
> speech to a dialect in broader use than their own such as they would
> hear on the BBC or from American news outlets. But for most of us, I
> doubt we would need spelling police. For example, if I write
> "schedule"
> with a "k" sound, and a Londoner reads it, I seriously doubt, he
> would
> have more than a moment's hesitation in deciphering the word even
> though
> he doesn't pronounce it that way.
>
> If we start insisting that every word must be spelt in accordance
> with
> an arbitrary standard that does not match anyone's speech completely,
> then we will be back to looking up many words and memorizing their
> spelling. It is my understanding that in Shakespeare's time, the idea
> of proper spelling did not exist, and the Bard was quite content to
> spell a word one way today and differently tomorrow. That apparently
> didn't hold him back We all have been prejudiced by our schooling and
> what Kingsley Read called the "cultural fetish" of spelling to reject
> the idea that we can spell words the way we want. If we go too far
> astray, our readers won't understand, and we pay the price of not
> being
> read. That by itself, forces a high level of conformism onto the
> situation, but to insist that we all have to spell in lockstep or be
> considered morons is quite a different matter.
>
> I have seen a number of people insist that we have to have
> standardized
> spelling or we are doomed, but I doubt anyone has actually studied
> this
> so we have no real data as to how an alternative English alphabet
> would
> work if it did or did not use standardized spelling. For example, let
> us assume that we don't insist on standardized spelling and that
> it was
> later found that that decision slowed the average reading speed by
> 5 or
> 10 % (I doubt it would be any greater than that). Would that not be a
> reasonable price to pay to avoid putting ourselves back in the
> position
> of attempting to memorize how words should be spelt rather than
> spelling
> them the way they sound in speech? I believe it would, especially for
> the dyslexics among us, who cannot deal with arbitrary spellings.
>
> If a person occasionally is unsure how to spell a word because he
> suspects he may pronounce it differently than others, he could always
> look it up in a dictionary. This is better than trying to memorize
> the
> spelling of virtually his entire vocabulary in order to have it
> comply
> with an arbitrary standard of speech.
>
> Paige
>
> John Cowan wrote:
> >
> > amd64_hacker scripsit:
> >
> > > Personally I'm for abbreviations in all texts.
> > > It seems to me that since QS is meant to be 'heard' it
> shouldn't matter
> > > how the word is written but how it is read.
> >
> > Well, yes, but that slows down reading to the speed of speech. I
> suspect
> > that rapid silent reading and standardized orthography go together --
> > we do know that fluent readers recognize familiar words by the total
> > shape of the word, slowing down only when they must to read an
> unfamilar
> > word, and that this is equally true in languages that are rationally
> > spelled, irrationally spelled, or not spelled at all (like Chinese).
> >
> > So if QS is going to become important for works meant to be read
> > more than once (as opposed to shorthand/transcription uses), a
> > standardized orthography will have to evolve.
> >
> > Which immediately leads to the issue of dialects. One's obvious and
> > natural phonetic orthography is another's stumbling block. ("Hmm,
> > is it spelled 'theft' or 'feft'?" "Hmm, does this mean 'lord' or
> > 'laud'?") A universal orthography ends up needing to make more
> > distinctions
> > than any one dialect actually needs, and thus to some extent becoming
> > artificial to all.
> >
> > --
> > John Cowan cowan@... <mailto:cowan%40ccil.org> <mailto:
> cowan% <mailto:cowan%25>40ccil.org <http://40ccil.org>>
> > "Mr. Lane, if you ever wish anything that I can do, all you will have
> > to do will be to send me a telegram asking and it will be done."
> > "Mr. Hearst, if you ever get a telegram from me asking you to do
> > anything, you can put the telegram down as a forgery."
> >
> >
>
>
